reviewText: Good little game. It’s a fun ride but you shouldn’t expect COD here. It’s an indie FPS game with small price. It is well made in my opinion though and I didn’t face any issue. I also played lots of multiplayer with my friend so far; if you have bunch of friends to create a server and join together its loads of fun.\nIn the end, I think it’s worth the price and I enjoyed my time with it.

reviewText:
This is one of those games when I would love that we have neutral option to review.

I can't be to harsh and critical because it is a indie game, and for indie title it is OK!

Let's start with gameplay, E.T. Armies is futuristic FPS with both single and multiplayer.
Single-player offers medium length campaign full with up's and down's, how's that?!

Well for start graphic ambiente is great, weapons designs also badass, music is also cool, but as a result of probably low development budget following stuff are not awful but very bad;
Overall sound effects, voice acting, NPC reactions and behavior (maybe the most stupid npc's I ever encounter) and explosion animations.
Story such as remind of old classic games, you are a badass dude going yolo killing and demolishing everything in his path. Also another annoying thing is that you do actualy have jump/space button, but you cant jump over anything that is higher than 20cm XD

I can't speak of multiplayer because whenever I tried playing it servers were empty, I do hope so that it is more fun than single-player. Game is crying for more players!

Dear devs you have my postive review, but keep improving the game. Good luck! :)

reviewText:
Before anything, I played E.T Armies at all three levels(Easy,Normal,Brutal) finished that hard work is really unbelievable!

The positive points of the game as good graphics, varied locations, good story, but short, the process was smooth and challenge missions.

Weaknesses in the game which are not few:
Aiming very hard, endless onslaught of enemies, the poor AI enemies and especially allies, silly Achievements (NEVER miss a shot and finish the game,Only use Parsis weapons to finish the game,Finish the game on Brutal level without dying,...), weak dialogue, sound effects low-quality (Soundtrack could be more effective) and etc
It was really amazing to me, harder to kill an enemy with the aim of killing without aiming, and when aiming and firing, the gun was shaking more !

There are very few players in multiplayer.
and unfortunately there arent Iranian servers & that's too bad

Finally i have to say, despite all the weaknesses, but when i was playing E.T Armies, my feels was so good cuz this game is made in Iran :)
it was enjoyable experience .
+like

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Disclaimer: The copy of this game was provided by the developer for review purposes

Few words about the game
E.T. Armies is quite a great indie shooter that shows us perfectly that game being independent, doesn't mean it has to be bad. Game is taking place in a sci-fi futuristic world and you're a soldier on a mission to rise and defend it as good as you can. No, it doesn't live up to some amazing AAA shooter, but you will be positively surpriced what indie developers are capable of.

Advantages
Graphics are polished and gorgeous, lots of of lightning and reflections do their job perfectly
Story is mantained on an interesting level for most of the time
Well made shooting mechanics
Multiplayer differs from singleplayer and it's really, really fun with all those addons like drones, spaceships, radar etc.
Dandy design of weapons and maps
Disadvantages
AI is terribly stupid, enemies see you through walls and obstacles and your allies doesn't help at all
World is closed by invisible walls everywhere
Music is very repetitive, sounds and voicing are poor and dialogues looks like written by a 14 years old boy
Multiplayer needs some development and publicity around as now it's completely dead
Price tag is too high for what the game offers
Summary
Game is good yet not outstanding. The idea of singleplayer is to run from point to point, killing waves of enemies that are spawning around you, but it's demanding and fun so that's something. Multiplayer is surprisingly good, I got to play with 4 other people in room and it was nice until I noticed that everyone camps with snipers. Kill streak rewards are also a nice addition to it. Except graphics, nothing really in this game is worth those 15 euro so it's too much in my opinion, but if you will get it at discount or bundled, totally worth trying out. But still, really good job devs, hope I'll get to play something from you in near future.

Personal score
7 / 10
If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

voteText: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Full Review - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NlToLSNZYsU

E.T Armies has the base workings of a competent first person shooter and even the beginnings of an extremely interesting world but it just fails to expand upon it. The level design is all basically long corridors, the graphics could have used a toning down in the bloom and lens flared effects, the sound randomly pulls you in and out of the game as it jumps between compressed and uncompressed sounding files and the story is just missing. However, in saying all of that, the actual gameplay of the game was enjoyable, not outstanding but enough to keep things entertaining.

If you’re after a quick first person shooter campaign that provides a decent challenge but not much more, then E.T Armies is worth a look. However if you were expecting a story rich, epic shooter, then this isn’t it.

reviewText:
The game offers no replayability, no character progression, and has a lack of content.
Once you've completed the game, there's no reason to start over. There are no collectibles, no new things, and only two differents environnement.
Multiplayer is fun, but after playing some games, you get bored very fast since there are no character progression, no new guns, no customization, nothing. You play a few games, and move on to a real multiplayer game.
Lack of content, multiplayer has two maps and it becomes boring very fast since there isn't much to explore. The campaign has a boring environment, and when you finish the game you would want to see more, do more different things, but there isn't.

reviewText:
As a game dev,
This game is a total mess.
It's beautiful, and the environements are pretty, but that's about it.

This game is an Unreal Engine FPS blueprint prototype, with maybe a few nice models mixed in, packaged together and thrown into the wild.

I didn't get to test the multiplayer, because nobody was online. Probably because the Multiplayer is a thrown in effort.
The developers and producers should have focused on either a good campaign, or a good multiplayer experience.
Unfortunately, because they tried to fit in both with probably a low budget, the game lacks equally bad on both sides.

reviewText:
This video features a non-biased  quick look @ the game only:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3yZrydF-W0c

I have to give this game credit for it's concept, vision and scope rarely seen in other indie titles.

Game Details:
E.T. Armies is an action-packed, fast-paced, science-fiction first person shooter. The game takes place in a dystopian future in which Earth’s resources have been depleted. Abandoning the planet seemed to be the only avenue for survival but not all could leave. Those left behind have become united in their struggle. It’s just the beginning for the Forsaken and the start of their devastating plan for vengeance. The Forsaken hungers for supremacy and power in equal measures and war is its lifeblood.

As a Parsis soldier you are charged to resist this new power and defend the fragile landscape against the Forsaken’s ruthless onslaught. Along the way you’ll face more strife than you could have possibly expected, together with your allies you must fight to cleanse the land from the Forsaken’s brutality.

reviewText: E.T. Armies is a sci-fi themed military First Person Shooter by a small Iranian studio, made in Unreal Engine 4. It's clearly not a triple-A title, but does show a solid degree of polish and professionalism; there are actual production values behind it, and it's not just a student programming project made by one or two dudes in their bedrooms (like a lot of First Person games on Steam these days). I'd say it's comparable in quality to other studio-developed Euro" FPS games on Steam
voteText: Chrome
commentsCount: etc (although the graphics are more modern than most of those games
column16: which were made in the late 2000's).\n\nGenerally
column17: the game plays like a typical modern shooter; you have regenerating health and can survive a reasonable but not overwhelming amount of gunfire
column18: can carry 2 swappable weapons plus a backup pistol
column20: enemies generally take 4 to 6 bullets of automatic weapons fire to kill depending on weapon
column21: etc. The one caveat is that movement speed feels somewhat slow (if anyone remembers Unreal 2
column22: that's how slow you move in this game)
column23: although you can sprint to move somewhat faster. There's no inventory management; your ammo is restored to full at ammo boxes spaced periodically throughout the levels
column24: although if you're using enemy weapons you need to pick up dropped weapons to refill ammo instead. Overall
column25: the gameplay and animations are a little stiff compared to an AAA release (or even something like the Metro series)
column26: but there are no glaring bugs or  major frustrations.\n\nThe Unreal Engine 4 graphics are very nice and up to modern standards (though not quite the bleeding edge photorealism of a AAA title)
column27: as previously stated the game has actual production values behind it and the graphics are a lot better than other UDK games on Steam that were made by one or two people. The only thing that looks a few years dated are the character faces
column28: and even those are OK. However most of the levels after the first one are somewhat disappointing in terms of art style
column29: as they all take place inside a generic sci-fi factory-type setting.\n\nLevel progression is very linear (no sidepaths and no exploration)
column30: although the levels themselves can be very large in scale. The game has about 6 levels
column31: with each level taking about 20-30 minutes to finish. Overall
column32: the game can be finished in a little over 2 hours
column33: which combined with the very basic small-scale plot and abrupt ending are probably the biggest weakness of the game.\n\nThe story is surprisingly small-scale
column34: and focuses on a single mission (to retake/destroy a power plant taken over by enemy soldiers) during a larger war between the Parsis (colonists who fled Earth after a global nuclear war) and the Forsaken (humans who were left behind on post-apocalyptic Earth). There are a couple hints of a larger plot (your character makes note of strange ruins in the desert
column36: and the Forsaken being more technologically advanced than they should be)
column37: but these plot threads never add up to anything concrete
column38: and the game ends abruptly with you simply blowing up the enemy base. Overall the plot feels like the first act in a 3 act storyline (i.e. the Modern Warfare games)
column39: which makes it seem the Devs ran out of time/money and could only put out the first act.\n\nThe cutscenes and dialogue are probably the weakest part of the overall presentation. Characters are reasonably animated in cutscenes
column40: although animation appears non-mocapped and seems on par with a mid-2000's game. However
column41: dialogue isn't lip-synced well and the dialogue itself is pretty poor (you can tell it was translated from a non-English script
column42: if you've played games like Chaser
column44: or Bet on Soldier you'll be familiar with this). It's not "Master of Unlocking" bad
column46: but there's just something "off" about it that makes it clear it was translated. Still
column47: since the plot itself is so basic this doesn't really hurt that much.\n\nWeapon variety is pretty basic. There are 3 assault rifles (the Parsis assault rifle
column49: and a stronger elite Forsaken assault rifle that can be picked up in the later levels)
column52: and a sniper rifle. Guns have a decent amount of recoil and your aim jumps when firing
column53: so you don't have laser-like accuracy even when Aiming Down Sights; at the same time you're still pretty accurate when hip-firing or running-and-gunning
column54: unlike say Call of Duty. Hip fire is accurate enough for normal combat
column55: though you do need to aim to be accurate enough to get headshots.\n\nEnemy variety is also basic; you have a standard soldier
column56: an elite soldier with a better rifle and more health (who looks EXACTLY like the regular soldier except for a slightly different-color uniform; camo grey instead of black)
column58: and a sniper. There are also wall turrets
column59: 2 different types of flying drone (one type has somewhat more health than the other)
column60: and an enemy aircraft that can only be killed with mounted turrets or special laser-targeter binoculars that take time to recharge. Enemy durability is on par with games like Killzone or the F.E.A.R. series
column61: with enemies dying after 6 shots from the Parsis rifle
column63: or 3 shots from the heavy assault rifle or pistol. Headshots from any weapon are an instant kill.\n\nGenerally
column64: the enemy A.I. and animations are also very basic. Enemies often stand or crouch in one spot while firing
column65: they do slowly strafe left or right when shot at
column66: and do make some usage of cover. I'd say the A.I. and animation quality is comparable to other "Euro" FPS games (Bet On Soldier
column70: etc). The enemy animations are functional
column71: though they do have a certain stiffness to them (I'd say it's comparable to the animations of the human enemies in the first Borderlands game). Enemies have a fairly basic animation/move set and aren't as fluid as in games like Call of Duty
column76: etc. There are a couple nice touches though
column77: such as enemies stumbling or doubling over when shot.\n\nI've heard there were some issues with rebinding keys
column80: but all of that seems to have been addressed and the game now has all the standard options you'd expect in a professional studio release.\n\nOverall
column81: if you play budget/Indie FPS titles and don't mind the basic
column83: you might give E.T. Armies a try.  It's pretty generic and basic
column84: but it's also competently made. If you generally stick to AAA releases
column86: you might want to skip it."

reviewText:
I'm having a blast playing this game a recording a playthrough of it. It's a UDK game and it really feels very good and is extremely enjoyable. You can take a look at my Youtube video to help you decide if it's worth it, but for the relatively small asking price, I can say that I definitely believe it is worth buying.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=khnohpIxMUs

This game is simply alot of fun. It doesn't do anything ground breaking or new, it's just a fun, on-rails FPS game with a pretty interesting story, a couple of intriguing characters and alot of fun gunplay.

reviewText: Meh. Game feels clunky, absolutely basic controls. Audio feels dated. The whole thing feels like a college student's project. While the lights and environments look good, the rest of the game feels like it should have been released four years ago.\n\nOn top of that, the multiplayer portion may as well not exist. Currently four servers available and all are empty.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nReally not worth your money and/or attention. It's a honest attempt at creating an FPS title, unfortunatly devs are lacking in skill and original ideas. E.T Armies is super-short. Single player campaign takes around 3-4 hours, multiplayer is dead on arrival. The whole game is just plain boring and never a bit exciting. Skip this, really.

reviewText:
Pros:

+ Graphics are certainly quite good-looking for an indie game
+ Gameplay is solid
+ Guns feel nice to use

Cons:

- Generic plot
- Laughably mistake-ridden dialogue
- Out-of-place voice acting (American voices but distinctly Arabic names...?)
- No option to turn off toggle iron sights
- Movement feels a little bit slow
- Weapons don't always hit their targets

reviewText:
Full Discloure i recieved a Press key from the Publisher but unlike most
others this did not effect my Review in any way.

Video Review https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Tmx0JH1qdE

I'l be Honest and say there is so little to ET Armies that it makes a review almost pointless.
Its easily described in a few short words as a Boring no substance or style generic of the most
Generic first Person shooters.Its more plain and boring then the Shooters of the 90s.

While yes it does have nice Visuals and asthetic the extremely lack luster Gun play
story voice acting and overall design just left me feeling bored and wanting to go take
a nap after playing it.Even in my own review i had to have Coffee after playing it to stay awake.

My more fresh and raw thoughts are in my Video review so its best to check that out.
But if you are not convinced then just play it get a refund then come back here.

And remember I told you so!

reviewText: Gameplay is boring. Guns lack impact. Why so many lens flare, did J. J. Abrams produce this game? Dudebro story is a dudebro story, but this is one of the worst I've ever played. Graphics are good enough, but it lacks detail. It felt I was playing an old game in that aspect. Voice acting is ok for an indie game. This game needs a lot more for it to be considered average in my opinion. I was curious about the game because it was made by iranians, but Raspina Studio really needs to do a better job for a next game. Improve your storytelling. Improve your enviroment detail. Improve your gameplay.

reviewText: When I watched the trailer for this game, I told myself; not a bad game, worth the money I guess. The voice acting is terrible, especially for the character we're playing as who I don't know for some reason sounded like an office jockey by the way of him refering to his superior as 'boss' all the time - Yes boss." "Ok boss." "Sure boss."

reviewText: Avoid this game at all costs. It is poorly optimized indie trash. Like most indie games it runs poorly. If you don't own a I hate money" rig then don't even bother. Even if it uses DX 9.0c. I bought this game cause it looked interesting. Then I found out it was a poorly optimized mess. I did a refund in a few hours. Thanks for the refund option
date: I didn't get screwed out of $11. The requirements for this game are very decieving. Don't trust them. I have more than enough hardware and it still ran poorly. I turned everything down to low or off and the game still gave me the same general FPS performance. That's how you can tell it's poorly optimized. Also before anyone says "Your PC is a potato"
recommended: no it isn't. I can run MGS 5 fin and a bunch of other games
hoursPlayed: GTA 5 is one of them. I might not get a steady 60 fps but GTA 5 looks better and performs better. The same for MGS 5. It's a shame western developers
voteText: even those big name western developers let a Japanese developer/publisher who mostly makes games for consoles make them look bad."

reviewText:
ET Armies Review

What do I think about ET Armies?

Pros
It has a decent story and some personality to it
The shooting mechanics are at least down to a science and feel like they are a good base
It has some play time to it, enough that you could get a decent play session out of it

Cons
There are better shooters out there
The graphics will never look as good as the screenshots here
The guns all feel mostly the same
The enemies aren't really that much of a variety
Enemies are pretty dumb
This is just an above average shooter
Infinite Enemy spawns in place of actual difficulty

Game Rating: 2.5/5
Rage Factor: 2/5

Video Review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H4pi9vPAVgE
